central sleep apnea: central sleep apnea disorders are frequently present in users of longacting opioids such as methadone individuals taking these medications have a sleeprelated breathing disor der that could contribute to sleep disturbances and symptoms such as sleepiness confu sion and depression while the individual is asleep breathing patterns such as central apneas periodic apneas and ataxic breathing may be observed obstructive sleep apnea hypopnea may coexist with central sleep apnea and features consistent with this condi tion can also be present see obstructive sleep apnea hypopnea earlier in this chapter cheynestokes breathing is more commonly observed in association with conditions that include heart failure stroke and renal failure and is seen more frequently in individuals with atrial fibrillation individuals with cheynestokes breathing are more likely to be older to be male and to have lower weight than individuals with obstructive sleep apnea hypopnea
